glossary.item: The person by whom a Passive Verb action is completed. Passive Verbs are often accompanied by an ablative of (personal) agent.
comes from two Latin adjectives: verus,a,um = truth; similis, simile = alike, similar to. Together, it means "like the truth."
Let us go on the greatest journey!

item.term: Post decem annos in mari, viri ad Troiam pervenient.

glossary.item: After ten years on the sea, the men will arrive at Troy.
in the middle of the night, he sailed

item.term: Eo tempore, perpetuam vindictam petere promisi

glossary.item: At that time, I promised to seek eternal vengeance

item.term: Feminae mihi dona, oves et boves dant

glossary.item: The women give gifts, sheep and cattle to me.
The most beautiful of all women.
The gift was a huge wooden horse!

item.term: Parce mihi. Ero non amica illo

glossary.item: Forgive me. I will not be friendly to him.

item.term: Post mortem suam, fabulam vastari cupivit

glossary.item: After his death, he wanted the story to be destroyed.
And so several hundred years later,
an original grouping of around 30 men who held wide powers in the early Republic
long cloak draped over the left shoulder
narrow strip tunic with two vertical purple stripes

item.term: Io trans Europam multos annos erravit.

glossary.item: Io wandered across Europe for many years.
Jupiter sent down Mercury to kill Argus.
I thought of a plan to help them.

item.term: Eo tempore ipso, meus frater, Neptunus, et ego, Graecos pugnare Troianos adiuvaverunt.

glossary.item: At that very time, my father, Neptune, and I helped the Greeks to fight the Trojans.
served as a judicial officer with civic and provincial jurisdiction
urban maintenance such as roads, food and water supplies, festivals
responsible for the census, elected every five years for a year and a half period
office to protect the rights of the plebian class and had to be from this class

item.term: mihi nomen est Mercurius, et ego sum saevus!

glossary.item: My name is Mercury, and I am a savage!

item.term: tum ego ad urbem Thessalius cucurri.

glossary.item: I then ran to the city of Thessaly.
a large bridge-like device on Roman battleships

item.term: Mihi nomen est Mercurius, et ego sum saevus!

glossary.item: My name is Mercury, and I am a savage!

item.term: Pyrrhus erat rex fortis Epiri, qui in Romanos pugnavit

glossary.item: Pyrrhus was the brave king of Epirus, who fought against the Romans.
The Romans had never seen elephants before.

item.term: Pyrrhus ad proelium Heracleae elephantos eius portavit.

glossary.item: Pyrrhus brought his elephants to the battle at Heraclea.

item.term: Viri Romani a pedibus elephantorum fracti et iacti sunt.

glossary.item: Roman soldiers were shattered and flung away by the feet of the elephants.

item.term: Tum, Apollo ad meum cavum volavit et accusavit me rapiendem bovem eius.

glossary.item: Then, Apollo flew to my cave and accused me of stealing his cattle.

item.term: Sum Senator, qui in Etruria habitat.

glossary.item: I am a Senator, who lives in Etruria.
As Senator, I give advice to the Consul.

item.term: In Roma, consul Romanus esse cupio.

glossary.item: In Rome, I wish to be a Roman consul.
Cult comes from the Latin cultus (colo, colere, colui, cultus,-a,-um -to nurture, to worship) which means the necessary acts of preserving active adoration towards deities, temples, and shrines.

item.term: Rhea Silvia, mater primi regis Romae, Romuli, erat virgo Vestalis

glossary.item: Rhea Silvia, the mother of the first king of Rome, Romulus, was a Vestal Maiden.

item.term: Sum in meo templo cotidie maneo

glossary.item: I stay in my temple everyday.
hired men paid to fight and who are not a member of any military group
I do not like Gaius Marius
The die is cast! This is a variation of a Latin phrase attributed by Suetonius to Julius Caesar on January 10, 49 BCE when Caesar had crossed the Rubicon River
an elaborate celebration given to a select few leaders after securing victory abroad
a sense of honor, respect, and worthiness that one holds
I came, I saw, I conquered.
These patricians supported the greater rights and influence in government for the common people.
Literally translated as 'the best,' they are the traditional nobility who supported the ancestral ways of Rome.
elected by the Tribal Assembly to manage the markets

item.term: Mecum galeam meam, scutum meum, gladium meum, et hastam meam porto—proelium paro!

glossary.item: I am carrying with me my helmet, my spear, my sword, and my shield—I am preparing for battle!

item.term: Ita, et in corpore et in animo vulneror.

glossary.item: Thus, I am wounded both in body and in spirit

item.term: Etiam numerum virorum in Senatu auxi.

glossary.item: And I increased the size of the Senate.

item.term: Cinna e Roma expulsa est. Sulla ad Romam revenit, filium Marii in itinere, et potestatem rei publicae recuperavit

glossary.item: Sulla headed back to Rome, killed Marius son on his way, and regained control of the Republic
From Latin in- (not) + de- (completely) + fatigare (wear out).
The Roman virtue of piety, faithfulness, and duty
the events of the divine Augustus
the greatest priest = the chief priest of the land
authority over the tribune of the plebs
They surrounded him and leaped upon him.

item.term: Meus amicus mortuus est et mea culpa est.

glossary.item: My friend is dead and I am the culprit.
In this sign, you will conquer

item.term: Miles, nobiscum fortissime pugna et veni!

glossary.item: Soldier, come and fight very bravely with us!

item.term: Etiam, ferociores peditus, equitatus, velites, et hastates Romanos video.

glossary.item: Also, I see rather courageous Roman infantry, calvary, light-armed infantry, and front-line soldiers.
The Ides of March. The word “Ides” on a Roman calendar refers to the first new moon of the month.
the first name or title of emperor

item.term: Tum omnia haec parva bella in Gallia et Brittania gesseram

glossary.item: Then I had waged all of these small war campaigns in Gaul and Britain

item.term: Nunc, sum Imperator, sed meum regnum erat breve

glossary.item: Now, I am Emperor, but my rule was short

item.term: Ita, populi fidem in me amiserunt

glossary.item: Thus, the people left faith in me
and I began to build the Coliseum!
Yes, that same Verona where Romeo and Juliet lived! Shakespeare was very familiar with the poems of Catullus and was inspired by him to write this famous play of his.

item.term: quas meus avunculus Vulcanus pro me fecerat

glossary.item: which my uncle Vulcan had made for me
a collection of lyric poems on various topics and devotion to Augustus.
to whom I became a great friend!
to whom I became a great friend!
I wrote elegy during the Augustan Age.
writing paper made from the stem of a papyrus plant
I was a great friend to Augustus
something that is happening as the main verb is happening
something happening before the main verb has happened
something that will happen after the main verb happens
commissioned by Augustus, a poem in Sapphic meter to celebrate the great Secular Games held once a century.
a poem written about the art of poetic writing

item.term: Primo, Mons Vesuvius erupit, vastans urbes Pompeii et Herculanii

glossary.item: First, Mt. Vesuvius erupted, destroying the cities of Pompei and Herculaneum.

item.term: Post id, de me solo putam

glossary.item: After that, I will be thinking about myself only
from the Latin parco, parcere, parcui, parsus,-a,-um, to be sparing
selecting the next two generations of emperors

item.term: Tum, quisque nostrum virum regere praeter nos leget

glossary.item: Then, each of us will choose a man to rule alongside us

item.term: Me et geminum fratrem, Apollonem, in insula Deli peperi

glossary.item: She gave birth to me and my twin brother, Apollo, on the island of Delos

item.term: pulchrior, honestior, et divinior quam Leto

glossary.item: more beautiful, more respectable, and more divine than Leto

item.term: Ut imperator Romae, in Roma habere non volui quod urbs in ruinas ceciderat

glossary.item: As emperor of Rome, I didn’t want to live in Rome because the city had fallen into decay
In this sign, you will conquer

item.term: Etiam meam Agrippinam ex Roma removere me adiuvaverunt

glossary.item: They also helped me remove my mother, Agrippina, from Rome.

item.term: Probiter, non amicum amiciorem Orione tenui

glossary.item: Honestly, I didn't have a friendlier friend than Orion.
Is he in love with you?

item.term: aliquem scriptorem qui mala de me scripsit

glossary.item: any writer who wrote bad things about me
I gave money to the people

item.term: Autem, potestatem exercituum tenere non potui

glossary.item: However, I wasn’t able to keep control of the army

item.term: Ut filius praesidis Romani, momentum militum cognovi

glossary.item: As the son of a Roman governor, I knew the importance of the military
A Triumvirate was a commission of three magistrates for the running of public affairs
my mother, Livia, was very influential
I spent most of my life
